dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, 38% above pre-pandemic levels for durable goods spending—that is a massive shift in consumer behavior.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, thirty eight percent above pre-pandemic levels for durable goods spending-that is a massive shift in consumer behavior.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, durable-goods spending in real terms is 38% above where it was at the end of March 2018, while services spending is only 15% higher, a 23-percentage-point gap in relative growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And services only up 15%—that 23-point gap is just wild. We really did cram like, two decades of e-commerce adoption into two years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And services only up fifteen percent-that twenty three-point gap is just wild. We really did cram like, two decades of e-commerce adoption into two years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, durable-goods spending in real terms is 38% above where it was at the end of March 2018, while services spending is only 15% higher, a 23-percentage-point gap in relative growth. At the height of the pandemic, we crammed a couple of decades worth of societal learning about leveraging e-commerce and the internet into just two years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the Fed had to walk this crazy tightrope—like, how do you support incomes without just turbocharging inflation?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the Fed had to walk this crazy tightrope-like, how do you support incomes without just turbocharging inflation?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The immediate challenge was to maintain consumers incomes in the face of sweeping lockdowns, supply-chain disruptions, and shifts in aggregate supply. This meant striking a balance between avoiding a depression and not goosing the economy with so much liquidity as to turbocharge inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm. And then there's that whole thing about sticky wages and prices—you can't just tell service workers to take a pay cut, so you needed some inflation in expanding sectors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm. And then there's that whole thing about sticky wages and prices-you can't just tell service workers to take a pay cut, so you needed some inflation in expanding sectors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since neither nominal wages nor prices were going to fall back to their previous levels (they are sticky, in the economic parlance), substantially cutting wages and prices in shrinking service-sector industries was a non-starter. Instead, creating more supply in the areas where there was growing demand required wage and price inflation in the newly expanding sectors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and now we're seeing these huge employment revisions—over 300,000 more jobs than previously thought? That's a pretty remarkable data point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and now we're seeing these huge employment revisions-over three hundred thousand more jobs than previously thought? That's a pretty remarkable data point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, the August number was revised upward by 72,000, which means there are 326,000 more employed workers than in the previous jobs report.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It makes you wonder if fiscal policy was way more effective than people assumed, or if the neutral interest rate just shifted up without us realizing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It makes you wonder if fiscal policy was way more effective than people assumed, or if the neutral interest rate just shifted up without us realizing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Has the US economy remained so remarkably strong because the effect of expansionary fiscal policy was more powerful than I thought? Or is it because the neutral rate of interest has risen substantially over the past half-decade, implying that the Feds monetary policy has been substantially less restrictive and contractionary than I thought?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the AI boom—like, could that turn out to be a bubble? So much optimism but not a ton of clear profit yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the A I boom-like, could that turn out to be a bubble? So much optimism but not a ton of clear profit yet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One obvious risk is that the ongoing AI boom will prove to be a bubble. While there are plenty of promising use cases for AI technologies, it is not yet clear how these will translate into increased business profits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. But honestly, after all that, it's like we're actually sticking the landing? A soft landing, against all odds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. But honestly, after all that, it's like we're actually sticking the landing? A soft landing, against all odds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For now, though, we should all enjoy the soft landing that the economy has made.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, real income revised up almost 4%—that's not nothing. Maybe we should just enjoy this moment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, real income revised up almost four percent-that's not nothing. Maybe we should just enjoy this moment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Real (inflation-adjusted) income as of the second quarter of 2024 has been revised upward by 3.6%, and the estimated level of real production which by definition should be equal to real income, save for a pesky statistical discrepancy was revised upward by 1.3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, no kidding. After the chaos, a little economic sunshine feels deserved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, no kidding. After the chaos, a little economic sunshine feels deserved.

HostA: Exactly. And the Fed had to walk this crazy tightrope—like, how do you support incomes without just turbocharging inflation?
HostB: Mhm. And then there’s that whole thing about sticky wages and prices—you can’t just tell service workers to take a pay cut, so you needed some inflation in expanding sectors.
HostA: Yeah, and now we’re seeing these huge employment revisions—over 300,000 more jobs than previously thought? That’s a pretty remarkable data point.
HostB: It makes you wonder if fiscal policy was way more effective than people assumed, or if the neutral interest rate just shifted up without us realizing.
HostA: And then there’s the AI boom—like, could that turn out to be a bubble? So much optimism but not a ton of clear profit yet.
HostB: For sure. But honestly, after all that, it’s like we’re actually sticking the landing? A soft landing, against all odds.
HostA: I mean, real income revised up almost 4%—that’s not nothing. Maybe we should just enjoy this moment.
